nodes.bodyText: Do I need to add the ASF iceberg license at the top of the file manually or will that happen on merge or in some other way?
Yes,  I think we should attach the license header in this file manually.
Yes, we need the ASF header.

Header has been added.
I wasn't sure if there was a process to automatically add it to new files. If the ASF infra team maintains a github api token which is accessible (as a secret that they rotate out or something), then it would be possible to have the license added to the top of all new files automatically.
This project doesn't use maven. Should we remove this? And what about the files that are also in .gitignore?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,83 @@
+
+# The following paragraph was taken from the Apache Spark project.
+#   see: https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/.github/autolabeler.yml
+# Bot page: https://github.com/apps/probot-autolabeler
+# The matching patterns follow the .gitignore spec.
+# See: https://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore#_pattern_format
+# Also, note that the plugin uses 'ignore' package. See also
+# https://github.com/kaelzhang/node-ignore
+
+INFRA:
+  - ".baseline/"
+  - ".github/"
+  - "/dev/"
+  - ".asf.yaml"
+  - ".gitattributes"
+  - ".gitignore"
+  - "baseline.gradle"
+  - "deploy.gradle"
+  - "jitpack.yml"
+  - "site/mkdocs.yml"
+  - "travis.yml"
+BUILD:
+  - "/dev/"
+  - "/project/"
+  - "/assembly/"
+  - "*pom.xml"

nodes.bodyText:
Woops this was left over from the version I was using in the spark project. I'll remove the maven references etc.
As for the fils in the .gitignore, I can remove those too if we'd like.

nodes.bodyText:
Unless I'm mistaken, any file in the .gitignore shouldn't be able to make its way into a PR, so that should not be a problem (unless I'm not understanding the question correctly).
The .gitignore file itself however is labeled as infra. Let me know if this does not cover your concern.

nodes.bodyText: These have been removed. Thanks for catching them. I used the spark project's autolabeler as a template and accidentally left those in there in my rush to get some eyeballs on these, as I didn't feel particularly qualified to make a decision on how things should be labeled - just willing to add the autolabeling.

nodes.bodyText:
I've removed this in favor of just dev/. Since PRs can have mutliple labels, I personally still feel that having a check on **.sh, which would match any file ending in .sh, would be good for future proofing but I will leave the call to your discretion. You've spent far more time than myself looking at PRs and mentally categorizing them.
Additionally, I'll be around to help keep this up to date as time goes on.  😄

Good call. I struggle with where to put these myself. I've made a LICENSE tag that will match any files (or directories technically) named LICENSE or NOTICE.
LICENSE:
  - "**LICENSE"
  - "**NOTICE"

+#   see: https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/.github/autolabeler.yml
+# Bot page: https://github.com/apps/probot-autolabeler
+# The matching patterns follow the .gitignore spec.
+# See: https://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore#_pattern_format
+# Also, note that the plugin uses 'ignore' package. See also
+# https://github.com/kaelzhang/node-ignore
+
+INFRA:
+  - ".baseline/"
+  - ".github/"
+  - "/dev/"
+  - ".asf.yaml"
+  - ".gitattributes"
+  - ".gitignore"
+  - "baseline.gradle"
+  - "deploy.gradle"
+  - "jitpack.yml"
+  - "site/mkdocs.yml"
+  - "travis.yml"
+BUILD:
+  - "/dev/"
+  - "/project/"
+  - "/assembly/"
+  - "*pom.xml"
+  - "/bin/docker-image-tool.sh"
+  - "/bin/find-spark-home*"
+  - "gradle/"
+  - "**.gradle"
+BASH:
+  - "dev/check-license"
+  - "**.sh"
+DOCS:
+  - "site/"
+  - "!/site/mkdocs.yml"
+  - "**CHANGELOG.md"
+  - "**LICENSE"
+  - "**NOTICE"
+  - "**README.md"
+EXAMPLES:
+  - "examples/"
+COMMON:
+  - "common/"
+API:
+  - "api/"
+  - "python/iceberg/api/"
+  - "python/tests/api/"
+CORE:
+  - "**/core/"

nodes.bodyText: This matches all files underneath a directory called core, that might be nested underneath 0 or more directories. I can remove them if we think that complicates things.

nodes.bodyText:
Ok. That sounds good to me. I was thinking in the case where python might get expanded out more in the future, but I am now leaning more towards your simpler is better approach.
I'll remove all of the matches for subdirectories.
